header.title: ESOTERIC EXTENSION OF TAROT TO DEVELOP SUPERSENSORY POWERS

central_thesis: This lesson, focused on Tarot Key 7 (The Chariot), posits that true supersensory power development stems from understanding and aligning with the Higher Self's 'Will,' which is distinct from the personality's ego-driven desires. The Chariot symbolizes the embodiment of consciousness, guided by the Self through the senses and intellect, and its mastery involves balancing opposing forces to achieve universal consciousness.

structure_content.chapter_title: LESSON 24: Transcriptions from Ann Davies' Class Lectures
structure_content.summary: The lesson introduces Tarot Key 7, The Chariot, as the culmination of the seven principles of consciousness and the first of seven keys dealing with the laws through which these principles operate. It explains that the Chariot symbolizes the seventh principle, attributed to Will, and represents the Self as the charioteer guiding the personality (chariot) through the senses (sphinxes) and intellect (reins). The physical body is depicted as a cube-shaped chariot, and the starry canopy represents universal consciousness. The text emphasizes that our true consciousness encompasses the universe, and problems arise from identifying solely with the limited personality. Will power is presented as fundamental but often misunderstood, with the lesson contrasting the true, universal Will with the personality's desires. It also touches upon the concept of the Higher Self, the eternal aspect of being, and its connection to the Creator, contrasting it with the mechanical response mechanism of the incarnating self. The latter half delves into the concept of choice, free will, and the potential for condemnation arising from misunderstanding. A personal anecdote illustrates the profound ripple effect of even a seemingly small decision, highlighting the interconnectedness of lives and the complexity of will. The text concludes by defining the true Self as inseparable from the universal pattern and explaining that true willing comes from this core being, with the individual serving as a specialized instrument. It further discusses the balance between severity and mercy, particularly in relation to ethical conduct and understanding immaturity versus evil, and concludes by urging self-forgiveness to prepare for the awareness of Divine Will.

key_concepts.definition: Symbolizes the seventh principle of consciousness and the attribute of Will. It represents the Self as the charioteer (Will) controlling the chariot (physical embodiment/personality) with the help of the senses (sphinxes) and intellect (reins). Its cube shape signifies the physical level of consciousness, and the starry canopy represents universal consciousness.

The seventh principle of consciousness, symbolized by The Chariot. It is presented as the fundamental basis of all accomplishments, often misunderstood. The text distinguishes between the true, universal Will of the Higher Self and the ego-driven desires of the personality.

The eternal, undying aspect of the individual, identified with the Creator, the true 'I,' or the 'I AM.' It is the true experiencer of all that occurs and the source of true willing. It is not separate from the universal pattern but is a differentiated ray from the One Spiritual Sun.

The limited sphere of experience and material form, often identified with the physical body and ego. Problems arise when consciousness is solely identified with the personality, rather than recognizing the broader scope of the Higher Self and universal consciousness.

Symbolize the senses, acting as the means by which the charioteer (Self) controls the chariot (personality). The text notes their dual nature (black and white, morose and smiling) representing the pairs of opposites.

Represented by the contrasting expressions on the sphinxes and the lunar figures on the charioteer's shoulders. The ability to handle these opposing forces is crucial for mastering the Chariot and achieving balance, often through the guidance of the Higher Self.
The totality of existence, represented by the starry canopy of the Chariot. The text asserts that individuals contain this universal consciousness within them, acting as miniatures of the universe.

A key principle in ethical conduct and occultism, symbolized by the Chariot's sphinxes and lunar figures. Maintaining this balance is essential; unbalanced mercy leads to weakness, while unbalanced severity is cold cruelty. This balance is credited to the Higher Self.

The assumption that individuals can choose between good and evil. The text explores the complexity and overwhelming nature of this concept, suggesting that actions are often dictated by the inescapable conditions of one's mind and development stage. True willing comes from the Higher Self, not individual whim.

practical_system.description: The text outlines a system for developing supersensory powers by understanding the seven principles of consciousness and the seven laws that govern them, culminating in the mastery of 'Will' symbolized by Tarot Key 7, The Chariot. The core practice involves recognizing and aligning with the Higher Self, which is the true source of Will. This is achieved through introspection, understanding the symbolism of The Chariot (Self as charioteer, personality as chariot, senses and intellect as controls), and consciously balancing opposing forces (severity/mercy, etc.). The ultimate aim is to transcend personality identification and realize one's connection to universal consciousness and the Divine Will. A specific, albeit allegorical, practice is suggested for the week: analyzing past conditions, identifying with the Higher Self's perspective, and practicing forgiveness (of self and others) to clear the way for recognizing Divine Will.

relevant_quotes.text: Tarot Key 7 symbolizes the seventh principle and embodies a summation of all of the previous keys. Its attribution is Will.

The Self as the rider in the chariot of personality. The sphinxes symbolize the senses; the mind is the reins. The intellect is the means used to guide, but the charioteer, or he who drives the chariot, is the Self.
We contain within our consciousness the sum total of the universe. We are miniatures of the universe, like reflections of the sun caught in a drop of water.
Will power is really the basis of all things and accomplishments, but nothing is more misunderstood than will power.
The Self represents that in us which is eternal, never born, undying. It is one at all times with the Creator, the true I, or the I AM.
How often Jesus said, "I have no will but to do the will of the Father, of Him who sent me."
This is delicate ground, but my responsibility to you is such that I must give you the true esoteric teaching...

It is the lust for money, the lust for anything in terms of material values that is harmful. It is the value that you place upon the material goal that matters, not whether it happens to be your karma at the moment to have more or less in material possessions.
Here is the real problem, the power to decide, the choice of good and evil!
The whole problem in understanding the enigma of will, of whether or not man has free will, is caused by a lack of definition of the term.
Your true Self is my true Self, and we are not different individuals but differentiated rays from the One Sun.
In initiatory rituals of the mystery schools, great emphasis is given to the fact that we must learn the balance between severity and mercy.
You have to reach a point at which you can credit the Higher Self, the divine level of consciousness--superconsciousness--with everything concerning yourself and others.

Unbalanced mercy is weakness, and aids and abets the sin, letting evil go unchecked, as it were. It strengthens the evil doer and the evil doing in the sinner. Therefore, to smile and say, "God will take care of him" if evil is being done in your presence, is like watching someone attack a child. That is unbalance between justice and mercy.
On the other hand, unbalanced severity as taught in esoteric work, is really cold cruelty. That is why we must balance both principles in order to cope with the problem of relative evil.
Be willing to forgive yourself. Thus will you prepare the way for the Supersensory awareness of Divine Will as the central power in the universe.

critical_analysis.relevance: This lesson is highly relevant to students of Western Esotericism, particularly those interested in the practical application of Tarot beyond divination. It bridges esoteric philosophy with practical psychological and spiritual development, framing 'Will' and 'Supersensory Powers' within a structured system of consciousness. The emphasis on the Higher Self aligns with Hermetic and Gnostic traditions, while the use of Tarot as a symbolic map is central to esoteric studies. The text's focus on balancing opposing forces and understanding the nature of 'Will' provides a framework for inner work and ethical development.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary audience is students and practitioners of esoteric teachings, likely those already familiar with basic Tarot symbolism and metaphysical concepts. It assumes a willingness to engage with abstract philosophical ideas and apply them to personal development. The language and concepts suggest an audience seeking deeper, practical understanding of consciousness and spiritual growth, beyond superficial occultism.
